newsitem.title: UK: Dated Brent trades lower again, Nigerian also slip.
newsitem.headline: Dated Brent trades lower again, Nigerian also slip.

text.p: North Sea physical crude values continued to struggle on Tuesday with no sign of any imminent recovery in differentials.
Dealers said a number of unsold mid-to-late November cargoes and an impossible arbitrage to U.S. buyers had kept the pressure Dated Brent in particular.
Two sales, Nov 13-15 at Dec -45 cents and Nov 11-13 at Dec -48 cts, valued the North Sea marker down on Monday sales.
Some dealers saw an element of CFD-related trading in the two deals but most agreed the market looked weak enough to sustain the numbers done.
Norwegian Gullfaks C, however, was able to command an unchanged premium of 24 cents over Brent for a Nov 21-23 loader.
"I don't think we going to see differentials for November cargoes get much better, but then again they probably won't get much worse either," said a North Sea seller.
West African spot markets weakened as an overhang of late November cargoes began to drag on first decade December values despite renewed interest from Far East refiners, traders said.
At least three Angolan Cabindas were sold late last week or on Monday to Chinese buyers and a distressed Nov 12-13 Qua Iboe moved to Indonesia around Dated Brent +47/+48 cents, they said.
But other Far East interest was concentrated in the second decade of December, leaving remaining November and early December barrels struggling.
Traders said another Qua Iboe was still unsold in November, along with two or three Escravos and a third decade Brass River.
Mediterranean Urals was looking firmer after trade last week cleared a prompt overhang.
Offers were coming from Dated Brent -95 cents cif Med compared with a deal at -$1.02 on Friday.
